facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 92 of 1957 filed by appellants.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 92 of 1957.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated May 11, 1956 of Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcutta in Misc. Case No. C-152 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 11, 1956, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcutta, in Misc. Case No. C-152 of 1955.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on September 20, 1957 by BHAGWATI J.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. September 20. The following Judgment of the Court was delivered by BHAGWATI J.-

facts.text: Appellant applied under s.22 of Industrial Disputes Appellate Tribunal Act, 1950 for permission to discharge respondent.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal with special leave against the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcut- ta, arises out of an application made by the appellant under s. 22 of the Industrial Disputes 66  Appellate Tribunal  Act, 1950,

facts.text: Respondent appointed as pay-clerk in appellants' cash department on April 30, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had been appointed as a pay-clerk in the appellants cash department on April 30. 1945,

facts.text: Respondent confirmed in service with effect from August 1, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: and had been company and had been companyfirmed in service with effect from August 1, 1945.

facts.text: Since beginning of 1949, respondent negligent, careless, disobedient, slow in duties.

anchor.surface_text: Since the beginning of 1949, the respondent was found to have become negligent and careless in his work and he was also disobedient and slow in the performance of the duties

facts.text: Chief Cashier complained by letter dated October 24, 1949 about respondent's negligence, sulkiness, disobedience, leaving money in open drawer.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently the Chief Cashier by his letter dated October 24, 1949, addressed to the Manager of the appellant, companyplained that he was very negligent and care- less in his work, and habitually showed sulkiness,

facts.text: Respondent submitted written explanation on October 28, 1949 attributing faults to ill health, hard work, mental anxiety, promised more care.

anchor.surface_text: The Management thereupon asked for his written explanation which he submitted on October 28, 1949, stating that if there was anything wrong on his part that was due to his ill health,

facts.text: Chief Cashier complained again on November 17, 1949 about no improvement, negligence, absenteeism, insolence.

anchor.surface_text: On November 17, 1949, the Chief Cashier again company- plained against the respondent stating that he had number only registered numberimprovement but was grossly negligent

facts.text: Charge-sheet submitted to respondent on November 18, 1949; suspended till enquiry disposal.

anchor.surface_text: A charge-sheet was submitted to him on November 18, 1949, and he was suspended till the final disposal of the enquiry.

facts.text: Respondent wrote to Managing Director on November 19, 1949 pleading not guilty, seeking interview.

anchor.surface_text: On November 19, 1949, the respondent wrote a letter to the Managing Director of the appellant pleading number guilty to the charges

facts.text: Manager investigated, found respondent guilty; respondent admitted rudeness, apologized; recommended transfer to Mechanical Engineering Department on November 29, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was granted an interview with the Manager of the appellant who investigated the case of the respondent and found him guilty of the charges framed against him.

facts.text: Appellant gave respondent one more chance, transferred to M.E. Department effective next day after November 29, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Following upon that report a letter was addressed by the appellant to the respondent on the same day intimating that the appellant had decided to give him one more chance

facts.text: Respondent did not improve; complaints from typists about chatter; Mr. Hooper gave verbal warnings, then written warning on February 9, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: In spite of these chances being given to him the respondent did number improve and he was again found seriously neglecting his work. There were also companyplaints from the typists

facts.text: Respondent replied to Hooper's warning on February 16, 1951 denying allegations, admitted talking but not excessively, promised improvement.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent replied by his letter dated February 16, 195 1, denying the allegations companytained in the said letter of Mr. Hooper

facts.text: Further complaints: work not proper, noisy, found sleeping twice by Mr. Girling; warning on September 3, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent however did number show any improvement and again there were companyplaints against him that his work had number been done properly

facts.text: Respondent replied to Girling's warning on September 8, 1952 denying most, excused sleeping due to illness.

anchor.surface_text: On September 3, 1952, Mr. Girling on behalf of the appellant gave the respondent a warning to which he replied on September 8, 1952,

facts.text: Management letter February 9, 1953: dispense services but gave another chance, stopped annual increment.

anchor.surface_text: In spite of these warnings the respondent showed numberimprove- ment in his work and companyduct and companytinued neglecting his duties

facts.text: Respondent protested stopping increment on February 17, 1953, claimed charges groundless.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent protested against the stopping of his annual increment by his letter dated Febru- ary 17, 1953,

facts.text: Labour Directorate of West Bengal refused to intervene on respondent's behalf.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Directorate of the Government of West Bengal was approached on his behalf but that body also refused to intervene.

facts.text: Mr. Hooper reported unsatisfactory work/conduct on August 19, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Hooper observed the respondents work and companyduct and number finding them satisfactory, by his memo dated August 19, 1953,

facts.text: Appellant letter May 10, 1954: terminate service with retrenchment compensation or apply to Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: on the strength of which the appel- lant wrote to the respondent its letter dated May 10, 1954, in which it stated that on receipt of the companyplaint from Mr. Hooper

facts.text: Appellant filed application under s.33 Industrial Disputes Act before Fifth Industrial Tribunal on September 21, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereafter filed on September 21, 1954, an application before the Fifth Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal. under s. 33

facts.text: Fifth Industrial Tribunal became functus officio; application struck off.

anchor.surface_text: The Fifth Industrial Tribunal however became functus officio on the expiry of thirty days from the publication of its Award

facts.text: Appellant filed application under s.22 before Labour Appellate Tribunal, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant eventually filed an application under s. 22 of the Act before the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India at Calcutta

facts.text: LAT heard ex parte, granted permission on October 14, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Appellate Tribunal companysisting of Shri N. Gan  President  and Shri P. R. Mukherji  Member  heard the appellant ex parte and by its order dated October 14, 1955,

facts.text: Appellant terminated respondent's service by letter November 11, 1955 offering retrenchment compensation.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant accordingly on November 11, 1955, wrote a letter to the respondent stating that the necessary permission had been granted

facts.text: Respondent filed affidavit for review on December 6, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: On December 6, 1955, the respondent filed an affidavit before the Labour Appellate Tribunal, Calcutta, praying for a review

facts.text: LAT allowed review, restored application on March 6, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Appellate Tribunal ... by its order dated March 6, 1956, allowed the respondents application and restored the appellants case

facts.text: LAT rejected application under s.22 on May 11, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: the Labour Appellate Tribunal ... rejected the application under s. 22 of the Act by its order dated May 11, 1956,

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant being aggrieved by the said decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcutta applied for and obtained special leave

facts.text: LAT found no prima facie case made out by appellant, no unfair practice or victimization.

anchor.surface_text: the Labour Appellate Tribunal recorded a finding in favour of the appellant that in termi- nating the service of the respondent as it did, the appel- lant was number, guilty of any unfair labour practice

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld LAT's refusal of permission under s.22.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the decision of the Labour Appel- late Tribunal refusing permission to the appellant under s. 22 of the Act was companyrect
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 11, 1956, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcutta, in Misc. Case No. C-152 of 1955.

This appeal with special leave against the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcut- ta, arises out of an application made by the appellant under s. 22 of the Industrial Disputes 66  Appellate Tribunal  Act, 1950,

issues.text: Whether the Labour Appellate Tribunal had jurisdiction to review its own order passed on October 14, 1955

anchor.surface_text: Re i It was contended that once the Labour Appellate Tribunal pronounced its order on October 14, 1955, it had become functus officio and thereafter it had no jurisdiction to review its own order. The circumstances, moreover,

anchor.surface_text: A question was mooted before us whether the words when hearing an appeal were to be read with the words Appellate Tribunal or with the words a civil court. It was argued that these words went with the words Appellate Tribunal and,

issues.text: whether in the instant case a prima facie case was made out by the appellant for terminating the service of the respondent and whether the appellant was motivated by any unfair labour practice or victimisation

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, got to consider whether in the instant case a prima facie case was made out by the employer for the lifting of such ban and the only jurisdiction which the Tribunal has is either to give such permission or to refuse it provided the employer is not acting mala fide or is not resorting to any unfair practice or victimization.

issues.text: Whether a charge-sheet and enquiry in conformity with principles of natural justice is required when discharging a workman simpliciter as opposed to punishing by dismissal

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sen endeavoured to draw a distinction between discharge on the one hand and punishment by way of dismissal or otherwise on the other, in clause b of s. 22 of the Act. He contended that no prima facie case need be made out when an employee was sought to be discharged simpliciter by the employer.

arguments.claim: s.9 IDAT Act invests LAT with civil court CPC powers for all proceedings whether original or appellate jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: Order 41 r. 21 provides Where an appeal is heard ex parte and judgment is pronounced against the respondent, he may apply to the appellate court to rehear the appeal...

arguments.claim: LAT has inherent powers under s.9(2) and O.3 r.4 to prevent abuse of process or for ends of justice

anchor.surface_text: This provision is analogous to that which is contained in s. 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure which relates to the inherent powers of the Court

arguments.claim: Prima facie case means possible conclusion if evidence believed, not only conclusion or full proof; LAT applied too high standard but evidence insufficient anyway

anchor.surface_text: A prima facie case does not mean a case proved to the hilt but a case which can be said to be established if the evidence which is led in support of the same were believed. While determining whether a prima facie case had been made out the relevant consideration is whether on the evidence led it was possible to arrive at the conclusion in question

arguments.claim: No prima facie case as Hooper reports not produced/proved; no opportunity to controvert; Dhar affidavit insufficient

arguments.court_reasoning: Evidence lacuna confirms no prima facie even at face value

arguments.claim: Appellant not guilty of unfair labour practice or victimization

anchor.surface_text: It is no doubt true that the Labour Appellate Tribunal recorded a finding in favour of the appellant that in terminating the service of the respondent as it did, the appellant was not, guilty of any unfair labour practice nor was it actuated by any motive of victimisation against the respondent.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ed with the same. Under the circumstances, we are of opinion that the decision arrived at by the Labour Appellate Tribunal which is the subject-matter

holdings.text: The Labour Appellate Tribunal had jurisdiction to set aside the ex parte order dated October 14, 1955, and restore the appellant's application under s. 22 of the Act to its file.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of opinion that the Labour Appellate Tribunal had jurisdiction to set aside the ex parte order dated October 14, 1955, and restore the appellants application under s. 22 of the Act to its file. This contention of the appellant therefore is without any substance and must be negatived.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.9 IDAT Act invests LAT with civil court powers under CPC for all proceedings (original/appellate); O.41 r.21 applies to rehear ex parte due to non-service; inherent powers under s.9(2)/O.3 r.4 prevent abuse.

holdings.text: Under s.9(1) IDAT Act, words 'when hearing an appeal' qualify powers of 'civil court' under CPC, applying to LAT's entire jurisdiction including original applications under s.22.

anchor.surface_text: Whatever the jurisdiction the Labour Appellate Tribunal is exercising-whether original or appellate-it is vested with the powers as are vested in a civil court under the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, when it is hearing an appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual construction avoids anomaly of no powers for original jurisdiction; cites Burmah-Shell and New Union Mills cases.

holdings.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal has inherent powers under s.9(2) IDAT Act and O.3 r.4 to make orders for ends of justice or prevent abuse of process.

anchor.surface_text: This provision is analogous to that which is contained in s. 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure which relates to the inherent powers of the Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.9(2) applies CPC unless inconsistent; O.3 r.4 explicitly preserves inherent powers like CPC s.151.

holdings.text: A prima facie case under s.22 is established if evidence led, if believed, permits the conclusion sought; not full proof or only possible conclusion.

anchor.surface_text: A prima facie case does not mean a case proved to the hilt but a case which can be said to be established if the evidence which is led in support of the same were believed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies standard from precedents like Buckingham & Carnatic; Tribunal assesses if view possible on evidence, without substituting judgment.

holdings.text: No prima facie case made out by appellant for permission to discharge respondent under s.22 due to evidentiary lacuna (Hooper reports not proved/produced).

anchor.surface_text: But if regard be had to the evidence which was actually led before it, there is such a lacuna in that evidence that it is impossible to come to the conclusion that even if the evidence was taken at its face value a prima facie case was made out by the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: LAT scrutinized material; Dhar affidavit & Hooper testimony insufficient without reports' contents or opportunity to controvert; applies prima facie standard to facts.

holdings.text: Appellant not guilty of unfair labour practice, mala fides, or victimization in seeking to terminate respondent's service.

anchor.surface_text: It is no doubt true that the Labour Appellate Tribunal recorded a finding in favour of the appellant that in terminating the service of the respondent as it did, the appellant was not, guilty of any unfair labour practice nor was it actuated by any motive of victimisation against the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicitly upholds LAT's finding; lenient treatment despite repeated misconduct shows no ULP/victimization.

holdings.text: Distinction between discharge simpliciter (no prima facie/enquiry needed) and punitive dismissal does not apply here as case presented as dismissal for guilt.

anchor.surface_text: This distinction sought to be drawn by Mr. Sen is therefore of no consequence whatever and need not detain us any further.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dhar affidavit states dismissal for guilt; ex parte hearing also framed as dismissal; obiter as not necessary to decision.

holdings.text: Decision of Labour Appellate Tribunal refusing permission under s.22 correct; appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal refusing permission to the appellant under s. 22 of the Act was correct and this appeal is liable to be dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholds no prima facie despite LAT's high standard; no ULP; cumulative holdings.

precedents.case_name: Lakshmi Devi Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Ram Sarup
precedents.cited_proposition: Tribunal under s.22 to consider only if prima facie case made out by employer to lift ban on discharge, without adjudicating dispute, absent mala fides or unfair practice
precedents.cited_holding: The Tribunal before whom an application is made under that section has number to adjudicate upon any industrial dispute arising between the employer and the workman but has only got to companysider whether the ban which is imposed on the- employer in the matter of altering the companydition of employ- ment to the prejudice of the workman or his discharge or punishment whether by dismissal or otherwise during the pendency of the proceedings therein referred to should be lifted. A prima facie case has to be made out by the em- ployer for the lifting of such ban and the only jurisdiction which the Tribunl has is either to give such permission or to refuse it provided the employer is number acting mala fide or is number resorting to any unfair practice or victimization.
